fullProgramDescription: The Bachelor of Science in Psychology provides a comprehensive education in the scientific study of behavior and mental processes. The program covers a broad range of topics, including research methods, statistics, cognitive psychology, social psychology, developmental psychology, and biological psychology. Students gain a deep understanding of the principles and methods of psychology, preparing them for careers in research, clinical psychology, education, and other fields.
shortProgramDescription: The Psychology B.S. program at UC San Diego provides a rigorous foundation in psychological theory, research methods, and statistical analysis, preparing students for diverse careers or further study.
classHighlights: The lower-division courses provide a foundation in psychology, including introductory psychology, research methods, and statistics. Students learn about the principles of psychology, research design, and statistical analysis.

Upper-division required courses cover cognitive psychology, social psychology, developmental psychology, and biological psychology. Students gain a deep understanding of the major areas of psychology and the research methods used to study them.

Electives allow students to explore specialized topics in psychology, such as abnormal psychology, personality, and psychological assessment. Students can choose from a range of courses to tailor their education to their interests and career goals.

The program also emphasizes the development of critical thinking, writing, and research skills. Students learn to design and conduct research studies, analyze data, and present their findings in a clear and concise manner.
learningOutcomes: Understand the major areas of psychology, including cognitive, social, developmental, and biological psychology.
Apply research methods and statistical analysis to study behavior and mental processes.
Demonstrate critical thinking and problem-solving skills in the context of psychological theory and research.
Communicate complex psychological concepts in a clear and concise manner.
Evaluate the ethical implications of psychological research and practice.
creditRequirements: 180 quarter units (includes major, general education, and elective courses)
additionalInformation: Students must complete the major requirements, including lower-division and upper-division courses, as well as elective courses. The program is designed to be completed in four years, with most students graduating within this timeframe.
